A Background (in every other sense) that is also dependent
on ancestor’s control state for the purpose of styling.
ControlButton is kind of button that is automatically
“control state updatable” for theme changes on the button
itself and potentially on a ControlBackground (layer) if it exists.
(This also presumes the button or super type (e.g. UIView)
conforms to ThemeAccessible or ThemeOverridable.)
This button is also Dismissable if “dismissive” is passed.
This button supports optionally constructing with data on
attachment (i.e. via in(..data:) method). The data type to
provide is a tuple of button text, optional button outset,
and whether or not to add a control background.
(You may create multiple buttons this way by providing
multiple data tuples as normal with ConstructibleWithData.)
Passing a theme to in() is optional but preferred (the theme
will be applied to the button as well as the background).
The default background type is ControlBackground but you may
also use a custom subclass of ControlBackground by subclassing
the button class and assigning the new background type to the
typealias UpdatableBackground. Example:
class MyButton : ConfirmButton { typealias UpdatableBackground = MyBackground }
If you pass a theme that inherits from the built-in theme
(via Theme.getBuiltInTheme()) then this button and it’s
background will inherit the default styling.
(If you want the background to receive the default styling
your Theme must also statically conform to ExtendedStyleAccessible
with the static property ExtendedStyleDefaults, with
usesButtonBackgroundLayers set to true.)
If you choose to use this initializer but do not want the
background to appear at all you may either hide it manually:
e.g. .with { $0.backgrounds }.hide()
or create a style in your theme to hide it:
e.g. MyControlButton.self > Background.self => .contentAlpha(0.0)
CAVEAT: If you want to use a custom Model type (not the one
that is already on ControlButton) you cannot use this class due to
generics limitations. Use DismissableButton or Button instead with
ControlStateCombinedUpdatable as necessary.
See also ControlButton2 that supports Shape based backgrounds.
